head.title: Hyundai Will Build Auto Plant in U.S.

hedline.hl1: Hyundai Will Build Auto Plant in U.S.

abstract.p: Hyundai Motor Co plans to invest more than $1 billion to build its first production plant in US; plant will be able to produce 300,000 vehicles a year, with cars scheduled to roll out in 2003 (S)

block.p: Seeking a greater piece of the world's largest market for automobiles, the Hyundai Motor Company plans to invest more than $1 billion to build its first production plant in the United States.

The new plant will be able to produce 300,000 vehicles a year, with cars scheduled to roll out in 2003, the company's chairman, Chung Mong Koo, said at the Paris motor show last week, according to a company spokesman, Min Hyung Joon. Mr. Chung was also quoted as saying that construction would begin in the second half of 2001.

Mr. Chung was also quoted as saying that construction would begin in the second half of 2001.
A site for the United States plant has not yet been chosen, the spokesman said.

Through generous after-service benefits in the last 10 years, Hyundai, South Korea's largest automaker, has tried to improve the reputation of its cars sold in the United States. The efforts included a five-year 60,000-mile warranty and a 10-year 100,000-mile after-service guarantee on engine and transmission parts.

Hyundai's stake in the United States car market rose to 2.7 percent at the end of August, compared with 1.7 percent a year earlier. Hyundai and an affiliate, Kia Motors, forecast combined sales of 390,000 vehicles in the United States this year.
In June, DaimlerChrysler agreed to buy a 10 percent stake in Hyundai Motor with an option to buy 5 percent more in the next three years.
